name: 9-bromofluorene
Reason: 9-bromofluorene has a melting point that we can compare to fluorene, which has a melting point of -172.0 degrees Celsius. The bromine atom introduces a significant increase in molecular weight and electronegativity, which raises the melting point. The fluorine atom also contributes to the melting point due to its ability to participate in hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +5 degrees Celsius. The bromine atom raises the melting point due to its ability to participate in hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +5 degrees Celsius. The presence of two additional phenyl rings linked in a linear fashion also contributes to the melting point. Phenyl groups, when connected to a benzene ring, tend to increase the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. In the case of 9-bromofluorene, we have two additional phenyl rings linked in a linear fashion, which would notably augment the melting point. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight.
